text: hi everyone gloom Denis doom tan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and it
is time for a review of the new richard
dawson album 2020 this is the latest
full-length LP from english singer and
songwriter richard dawson who in my
opinion has been one of indie Fulks best
kept secrets for the past decade or so
over the years dawson has amassed a
strange but versatile discography which
piqued my interest with the release of
his album peasant a few years ago a
project that featured basically an hour
these neo medieval folk songs with bold
but blemished acoustic guitars basically
archaic noise Foulke and through some
very animated vocal performances Dawson
would tell these stories inspired by the
days of yore mentioning cauldrons and
kingdoms and soldiers while also singing
about the dark and savage side of this
era to the abject poverty selling
children for grain Richards latest
project here is a change of pace though
of course the antiquated but updated
English folk isms that have inspired
much of Dawsons discography also carry
over onto 2020 but there's a lot more
electric instrumentation here there are
some weird synths and vocal effects
occasionally drums too this album is
very much a product of our modern era
not just in its sound but in its lyrics
too I mean the title of this thing is
2020 it's very obviously looking forward
to the very near future with one song
after another reading like a slightly
dystopian take on our late stage
capitalists present there are tracks on
this thing referencing our current day
problems with modern technology our
environment the political landscape also
workers toiling away in an Amazon
Fulfillment Center and even though this
project is different the matically and
sonically from Richard Dawson's previous
peasant there are some interesting ways
in which these records parallel in their
runtime in the melody writing both
albums actually feature a song titled no
one a short little interlude track on
the second to last song of the record
and even though both these albums are
from different time periods narrative
Lee they both feature stories with
protagonists that are essentially caught
in or struggling against the prevailing
problems of the society
they were born into so in a way it's
safe to say that peasant in 2020 our
sister albums or connected or one is the
sequel to the other and in my opinion
2020 is every bit as ingenious and
creative as its predecessor though maybe
Dawson's lyrics on this one are bit more
cutting because he is a product of the
era that he's critiquing and while I
really do love the ideas that Dawson is
putting forward on this album the
instrumentals in my opinion are just as
intriguing the explosive tracks
civil-servant is an amazing kick-off to
this project at the very start with
these grunting grinding off-kilter riffs
paper bran that mechanical repetition I
feel like I'm being ground into the
gears of a failing society or chased
down by a madman with a knife after this
we quickly transition into these tense
narrative verses the day for our
protagonist begins very mundane getting
up morning pouring some cereal and being
subjected to another day at a job that
you despise we get an epic triumphant
chorus on this one with some odd
falsetto vocals some of the medieval
elements of peasant really come back
during moments like this our protagonist
goes into these inner thoughts later
into the track about wanting to beat a
co-worker's head in basically to a
bloody pulp wanting to call in sick and
struggling with processing the traumas
of the people that this person has to
deal with which all sounds little
self-centered
yes but Dawson's characterization of
people in these civil servant positions
isn't too much different than what is
often reported by people who are social
workers in the u.s. working crazy hours
dealing with a lack of resources being
worked to the point where you're jaded
and you don't care about your job
anymore just take it as the Avant noise
full UK version of take this job and
shove it
Dawson reels it back in a little bit
with the much less noisy the Queen's
head which is a sobering tale about an
English town flooded which when
researching I saw is not too uncommon of
an occurrence in the UK with notable and
recent floods happening in oh seven oh
eight oh nine twelve and fifteen
I love the plucky weird folky
instrumentation on this track the grand
rush of synths and vocals on the hook
but most interesting on this track are
the vivid descriptions of people dealing
with this ordeal whether it be the vape
shop guy ferrying his chocolate labs on
a leaky kayak or a local butcher handing
out food while loudly proclaiming the
lack of flood defences is because of
foreigners coming over and making use of
public services and of course we have
the genius mantra on this track of how
little we are basically depicting
humanity as being helpless in the face
of the wrath of nature which they are
stirring through the destruction of the
environment then Dawson dishes out two
of the catchiest song is on the entire
record with two halves and jogging the
come on come on refrains on the former
are just too good I also love the
galloping groove on the latter two and
while it seems like Dawson is singing
from the standpoint of other people on
this record much of the time his
descriptions of dealing with anxiety on
this particular cut just seemed too
detailed to not come from a personal
place next we have the track heart emoji
which sees the skipping muted guitar
lines repeating along with these
sporadic synth embellishments that are
very gentle essentially it's a song
about finding out that your partner is
cheating by seeing some texts on their
phone the whole thing comes to a bloody
end that I won't totally spoil but I
think that Dawson's character comes to
the conclusion that some infidelity is
going on pretty fast and maybe the
ending would have been more interesting
a little less absurd if the protagonist
had realized he had come to a false
assumption or something the song black
triangle has one of the loudest and
weirdest intros of any track on here it
feels like a warp take on some classic
arena rock song with grimy guitars and
these fast little synth chords do it's
like listening to the who's who are you
but nightmare version the whole thing
quickly transitions into these fast
angular post-punk guitars and drums
black MIDI fans take notice so you have
this long winding multi-phase song
structure these hard grieving verses and
all this is attached to a story about a
guy who had a run-in with a UFO then he
becomes obsessed with UFOs to the point
where he has a website and a YouTube
channel where he tracks sightings his
obsession seems to be destroying his
marriage
- it's a hilarious and enthralling song
about getting caught up in a very weird
thing but there you have it also the
zany vocal harmonies during the last
climax of the song are fantastic it's
like in listening to a sci-fi folk Punk
epic then we have fulfillment center
which is a 10 minute long track and
maybe has way more for thought put into
it than any song about working in a
fulfillment center should but I think
Dawson does a great job of depicting the
daily health at people who are caught in
these types of jobs have to face the
repetition all the products having to be
shipped at such a fast pace people
falling asleep on the job or disgruntled
workers being escorted off the premises
also having your movements and your work
be timed and peeing into a bottle
because you can't go to the bathroom
Dawson also depicts this work as being
an endless cycle with his protagonist
saying that there is nothing left of
them by the time they go home before
they have to just go to sleep and wake
up again to just start all over
freshers ball is a decent low key moment
in the tracklist here it's a so-so song
about feeling lonely and missing someone
while also finding solace in some little
things and some silver linings of these
clouds and the closer dead dog in an
alleyway is a really climactic end of
this record the grim imagery of the dead
dog and having trouble finding a place
to sleep and rest juxtaposed against the
cold and callous never-ending movements
of the city which Dawson depicts as a
labyrinth of neon which is one of many
moments of poetic genius across this
project I'm really loving this one I'm
living the [ __ ] out of this one what a
challenging smart witty fun and
unsettling contribution to the full
catalog I'm also loving the personal and
story centric songwriting throughout
many of these tracks - which in a way
reminds me a little bit of mark kozilek
Sun Kil moon but obviously a lot of the
storytelling here is much more dystopian
and the instrumentals are coming from a
totally different planet then there's
also the case of Dawson singing which is
just so expressive I think that Dawson's
voice - many newcomers might sound a
little homely but it certainly fits
there
snugly in these very sour and oddly
catchy instrumentals if you're looking
for a more pleasant and breezy and eful
experience you might want to avoid this
one maybe but personally I'm loving how
unique and daring this project is I
think that maybe it would be great if
all of the themes and the stories tied
together and in some way conceptually by
the end of the whole thing they don't
it's really just a collection of tracks
but there's a great amount of focus
amongst all of those songs and and a
hell of a lot of great playing creative
writing very memorable lyrics and
stories and even though this thing is so
dense it is so replayable at least for
me anyway I'm feeling a light too decent
